threats.title: Developer commits secret to Git
threats.description: A Developer commits secrets to version control either accidentally or on purpose. An angry employee with read access to the repository finds the secrets and proceeds to use them to steal end-user  data
threats.mitigation: Adhere to the principal of "Need to Know" and ensure that production secrets are not shared with individuals wo don't have a need to know.

threats.title: Developers laptop gets stolen
threats.description: A stolen device can be potentially be used to access git and other development accounts.
threats.mitigation: Ensure encryption on all company devices.

threats.title: Malicious code injected into github actions instances
threats.description: An attacker could inject code into software pushed to github actions, which is then run with elevated privileges.
threats.mitigation:
Restrict the scope for various github actions runners.
Audit runners with various tools such as SAST.

threats.title: Secrets hardcoded
threats.description: Secrets could be hardcoded into repository code
threats.mitigation: Automated tools such as frogbot can be used to scan for secrets and other similar vulnerabilities.

threats.title: Dependency tampering
threats.description: External / open source dependencies could be compromised and malicious code could be added to them.
threats.mitigation:
Use automated dependency analysis.
Use a combination of lock files and code review so that dependencies can be trusted.

threats.title: Tampered Images can be published
threats.description: An attacker could gain access to the container repository and push a malicious image.
threats.mitigation:
Separate developer and production repositories.
Restrict access to the production repository, so that only the CI/CD pipeline can access it.
